comments.commentBody: Wait, Ireland had the lowest corporate tax rates in Europe and probably one of the lowest in the world. I thought that was  recipe for Nirvana and permanent prosperity. What happened?

The United States is next, especially California. Where they are now giving illegal immigrants not only enrollment but in-state tuition. Hey all you rich internationals students that want to study in the USA, come here on vacation...jump ship enroll in our public high schools and then you will save your parents money on a California State College degree. America we have been a rich country for too long, we forget we are poor now. Get serious.

What a shame that unlike us, the Irish cannot print their own money and are not duplicitous enough to change their accounting rules like we did, so that their banks could be made to appear in good shape.

At the end of the day it is all smoke and mirrors in the financial world but eventually the smoke gets so intense that the mirrors get clouded over. Then the party ends with a crash by which time the looters and the speculators have walked away with all of the bounty.

We must be nuts not to close down our completely contrived financial system that is a total farce before it destroys us all
I had a much easier time today (Tuesday) than yesterday - a lot of Monday's clueing had me confused. A lot of today's turned into laughs with double-meanings. G'night -

I wasn't too far off my usual time in solving this puzzle. But I didn't bother figuring out the theme until I was already more than halfway finished since it wasn't critical to my solving experience. I enjoyed the challenging clues and interesting fill. I got GO FISH immediately. That was a game I played often as a child.

#9 Joon's solution doesn't work if the first egg drop breaks. Going down from there is not an option. Of course, knowing something about eggs might help. I don't think any egg in existence today would survive the first floor. So, how many drops? One from the first floor. Why is everybody assuming more survival powers to the medium that they know, from experience, it doesn't have? Not math at all. Simply common sense.

Much better for me than yestreday but thought the theme was a little blah. Didn't we have something recently that required turning corners? I did like the long downs--all of them and also GO FISH.

@wags 2--I think it's an odd clue, too. I never thought "turned the tables" as necessarily involving winning or losing parties and nothing to do with leading or regaining it. I always thought it meant beating someone at his/her own game. The sources I find say it originated with backgammon. Makes sense to me because I've heard a player's inner board referred to as a table.

comments.userDisplayName: The Artist Formerly Known As Bakes
comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
Good item Toni... unfortunately Eli has been getting a lot of unfair criticism over the interceptions thrown this season. Below is an excerpt from Bill Pennington's article today questioning that particular play.

"The Giants’ best chance to retake the lead came midway through the second quarter, when they faced a third down at the Cowboys’ 2. But Manning inexplicably threw quickly to his left, firing the ball directly at defensive back Bryan McCann."

Now to be fair... the "inexplicably" could be in reference to Gilbride's play call, questioning the pass play vs. a run play. However, if that were the case then it certainly could have been better written. More likely, it seems he's questioning Eli's decision to throw the ball to Nicks. The play makes perfect sense and with Nicks' size advantage (essentially a post-up in basketball) we score on that play or get interference 90% of the time.

Unfortunately the only thing that went wrong with that play was the execution by the receiver. Aikman called it as soon as it happened, Eli's interaction with Nicks on the sidelines hinted at receiver error, Coughlin confirmed it... as did Eli, in the press conference later. Why then was the play "inexplicable" to Bill Pennington??

Good call, good throw... great defensive reaction to poor receiver play. Nicks, for all his talents is still young and learning the position (not that I profess to be some expert). He'll only get better... for our purposes however he needs to steepen the learning curve for us to realize our full potential this season.

comments.userDisplayName: The Artist Formerly Known As Bakes
comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
Good post by AH2 @#10... better post by Max @#12.

I'm a big fan of McNabb... but even I was getting ready to start back rooting for the Cards (huge Warner fan as well) in anticipation of him going there next season. I'm as confounded by this as anyone, and only serves to underscore the egregiousness of Shanahan's actions the past couple weeks. So unsettling was the issue that Dan Snyder saw it necessary to make a good faith showing to soothe McNabb's justifiably bruised feelings.

For those decrying the move... remember that NFL contracts aren't guaranteed, and furthermore, seems that only $10 million of the reported $78million is guaranteed. Meanwhile McNabb has a chance to earn more money with his play, keep some butts in the stands, and act as a functionable placeholder/custodian until the Redskins lates "quarterback of the future" can be drafted. In reality this may turn out to be a sensible 2-3 year signing.

When the dust settles, she will do a good job - and all this fuss will be forgotten.

Experts in education have given us what we have.

Those who do well - do well.

The complainers are the usual collection.

Losers.

Bloomberg says that those who oppose Black "don't get it."
Well, Mr. B. maybe we DO get it. Maybe we think education should not be based on the same principles as "business". Maybe we don't think everything in life is a business. Maybe we have other values than you. Maybe because you think all we need is a good (business) manager, we think we need an educational leader. Maybe the chancellor can be a "world class" educator and we can have a business "manager" report to them!
Yes, maybe we get it. Maybe you don't.
Mr. Mayor.  It is not about money.  It is about the democratic process airing out issues.  Dictator appoints.  Democracy  chooses.

After Michelle Rhee's resigning in D.C. I asked a Washington Post education writer in an on-line chat what qualifications Rhee brought to her job. He said she was highly recommended by Joel Kline.  What a laugh.  Maybe Bloomberg truly believes he is the Superman people have been waiting for.  Maybe he is grooming Black to be his VP.  I feel sorry for the citizens, teachers, and students of New York.
Impeach Bloomberg!

now you know why electing Bloomberg was a big mistake?

this really annoys me - this Bloomberg dude who probably sent all his kids to a private school decides its OK for a newbie to determine the future of thousands of kids?

Would he even ever let someone with no babysitting experience take care of his children?

Never mind Black's lack of the normal credentials--she doesn't even have the credentials for the waiver!

The state law doesn't allow just ANYONE to get a waiver. It sets forth standards for even waivers. It states that a waiver can be granted to candidates who are “exceptionally qualified [and] whose EXCEPTIONAL TRAINING and experience are the substantial equivalent of such requirements *AND* qualify such persons for the duties of a superintendent of schools.” (Emphasis mine, obviously.)

So aside from the Ms. Black's inappropriateness for the job, there is also a legal argument that she cannot be given the waiver.

"Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been frank about why he took pains to keep his search for a new schools chancellor secret, saying he wanted to avoid a public spectacle." (NYTimes).

So much for public office transparency, Mike.

There are a few notable problems w/Ms. Black's potential selection:

She has NO EDUCATIONAL curriculum or organizational expertise.
She is connected to publishing.
She is connectd to billionaire donors/special interests.
She has remained silent about her thoughts on reforming NYC schools.

Her selection reminds me of Dubbyuh's nomination of Harriet Myers to the Supreme Court; atleast Myers had trained as a lawyer!

"The opposition has coalesced slowly, partly because of the mayor’s tight grip on the city’s political sphere, which is strengthened by his popularity and his vast financial resources. "

Popularity? Bloomberg barely won in 2009 and only because of his wealth and a mediocre candidate. He is not popular and this sorry episode explains why.
If Mike is so rich, why isn't he smart?

It's time to halt the imperious, imperial mayorship and get real. New York is in desperate need of a Schools Chancellor, not just because there is a vacancy coming up but becuase there has been a vacancy. For years! It's a professional position, calling for a professional with training, experience and references. In other words, the whole shebang. This corporate personage the mayor has put forward would never be allowed to have any sort of position in almost any school system in the country, and yet he's willing to put her into the top job. The problem is that he is so ignorant of what it takes to be a good chancellor that he thinks that as usual, a CEO-type can do anything. Not true. At all.

And to all those who think we New Yorkers deserve this, I and most of my friends NEVER voted for this mayor. So we have a perfectly good right to complain. We tried to get someone else in and failed. But failure here is not our failure. It's much bigger than that, unfortunately. It's failure for the kids and after that the domino effect takes in way too many. Time to turn things around.

Mayor Bloomberg has a history of choosing leaders from the business community. His decisions have proven to be good for the city. This backlash against the Mayor may run deeper than the selection of Ms. Black. I wouldn't be surprised if some people want the Mayor to pay for an earlier controversial stance.

"Mr. Bloomberg plans to submit a letter to the state this week arguing that Ms. Black’s business acumen is needed in a time of financial peril."

Isn't this the exact same canard that Mayor Bloomberg used to justify his outrageous manipulation of the system to get a third term in office?

No one believed him then. Why would anyone believe him now?

Bloomberg suffers from the delusion that schools can be run like businesses; that students and teachers are only as good as their latest test score results.

I had worked as an ESL Coordinator in District 6 schools during the late 1980s and early 1990s. Our ESL program was considered one of the two most effective programs in New York City. Along came a hotshot, abrasive, know-it-all Superintendent who decided that all District educational programs had to be micromanaged. He fired all the veteran, excellent Coordinators and replaced them with "yes" men and women who echoed his "vision". The result was that principals, teachers and students were totally demoralized by the mechanical, business-like approach to education. Every student was expected to progress and frequent testing was implemented to ensure that "goal". Forget about individual differences. The District schools were run as they might have been in a fascist state.

Fortunately, the Superintendent soon moved on to greener pastures. Bloomberg would have loved him! Nobody else did.

This is what you get when your mayor does politics as a hobby.  As his third term drags on interminably, for him, and he is finally a lame-duck, thank goodness, and his national aspirations have tanked, and his much-vaunted achievements in student performance are revealed as a product of smoke and mirrors, he is becoming more and more petulent and even less concerned with how his actions are received.  One might even say that this bizarre appointment is his version of a Bronx cheer to the parents and educators of the city's school system.

The mayor simply offered this job, which affects millions of people, to his personal friend?  This smacks of the worst Bush-era cronyism.  This is Iraq Coalition Provisional Authority cronyism.  This is like when a 19 year old American kid was given the job of running the Baghdad Zoo.  A destructive shame.
